MACE USE PLANNED

LATE
Ed. Note: the following statement by Wesley Taylor, Hopkins Plant
Manager, was sent to the News-Letter after this issue's copy had gone
to the printer. The regular text of the article and the related editorial
on page 4 were written before receipt of this statement. As of Tuesday, according to Mr. Taylor's office, the only factor holding up the
purchase of Mace was the possibility that its effects would be harmful. There was no explanation for the change in policy which transpired between Tuesday and Wednesday evening.
There has been considerable discussion among members of the
student body, representatives of the Plant Manager's Office and the
University administration regarding the security of the Campus and
the arming of Campus police.
This statement has been prepared to put these discussions in perspective and to set the record straight.
Effective immediately, and until further notice, Campus police
officers will not be equipped with side arms.
They will not carry chemical mace.
They will not use "police dogs."
However, it is important to note that the Campus police are
charged with the general protection of students, faculty, employees
and University property. They must fulfill this task under circumstances today which are presenting them with more serious situations
than in the past. There have been more attempts at burglary, and
other crimes, including attacks on individual members of the University community in recent years than in the past. In order to carry
out their duties adquately they must be properly equipped.
Discussions will be held promptly to determine what equipment
they should have in order to meet their responsibilities and to protect themselves from physical harm from intruders. A final, policy
statement will be issued following those discussions.
Hopkins has decided to supply its security personnel with chemical Mace, a sometimes deadly compound produced by the General
Ordinance Equipment division of Smith and Wesson Company and
used by more than 3,000 U.S. police departments.
According to Robert Bilgrave,Director of Student Affairs, George
Weinbach, Campus Security Chief, and William Campbell, Assistant
to the Plant Manager, the addition of Mace to the University arsenal
became necessary after a series of recent molestings in front of the
Eisenhower Library.
Officials hope that the chemical will act as a deterrent, and pointed to the deteriorating neighborhood around the Homewood campus
and the soaring crime rate as justification.
Marauders
Mr. Weinbach expressed fears that bands of marauding teenagersknown to frequent the campus present a danger to unarmed Hopkins policemen and students. "Hell, all we're trying to do is defend
the campus."
Present policy permits individual policemen to decide for themselves whether or not they wish to carry guns. However, three out of
five have declined.
The Graduate Club, under the leadership of President John Ferchak, voiced its disapproval of the use of arms and Mace, and requested the administration to look into other means of defense such
as increases in lighting and guards.
Academic Council
Dr. John Owen of Political Economy plans to bring the matter
before the Academic Council, and Mr. Bilgrave is scheduling a special
meeting of the Committee on Student Affairs for next week.
According to Mr. Weinbach, decisions on campus security are
made by the Plant Manager's Office in consultation with Homewood House. Inexplicably, John Peach, another Assistant Plant Manager,
denied the University's planned acquisition of Mace.
Chemical Mace contains 5 per cent methyl chloreform, an industrial solvent,and less than 1 per cent tear gas, phenylmethylchloroketone. In the May 6 issue of Newsweek Magazine, Dr. Lawrence Rose,
a practicing San Francisco opthalmologist claimed that Mace can
cause "substantial damage to the eyes, skin and respiratory system."
Mace Damage
Dr. Rose claims, "Of the nine cases of Macing I have examined
thoroughly, four patients had second degree facial and eyelid skin
burns with deep redness, blistering and pain for 24 to 72 hours and
skin pigment changes lasting two to five weeks."

Dr. Marvin B. Perry, President
of Goucher College, indicated that
Hopkins and Goucher will eventually enjoy closer ties than are
evident today.
Dr. Perry was inaugurated as
Goucher's seventh President on
May 3 of this year.
The present program of student exchange between the two
universities is drastically hampered
by incompatible calendars. Perry
explained that because Goucher is
on a trimester system, examination and vacation schedules for
Hopkins and Goucher do not
coincide. Similarily, due to the
differing length of the semesters,
courses at Hopkins cover substantially different material. This
condition makes it difficult to
complete departmental requirements in an inter-university program.
Perry stated that Dr. Swanson,
Hopkins' Dean of the Undergraduate Faculty and his counterpart at Goucher are presently
attempting to resolve the major
conflicts preventing a close Goucher-Hopkins relationship. Perry
hopes that a compromise on such
issues as calendar reform may be
achieved between the two schools.
Perry further hopes that the
faculty chairmen will be able to
work together in order to avoid
major course conflicts. "There are
now several popular courses at
Goucher which are not available
to Hopkins' students because of
such conflicts" he said.
There is, in addition, some
hope that a viable system of
transportation between the two
schools may be initiated. "Such a
system will greatly facilitate interschool programs". There is, however, no indication that Goucher
and Hopkins will merge at any
forseeable future date.
Dr. Perry stated that "from
here, there are no limits to what
can be done. Everything depends
on the desires of the undergraduates, however." There must be
strong undergraduate support before this program will be
successful.

run, his name was listed on the ballot, and he received 5.63%.

Kennedy 213,576, Mr. Nixon 196,870, Governor Rockefeller
115,783, and President Johnson 57,244 votes.
Former Governor George Wallace of Alabama received 33,044
votes, or 3.25% of the votes cast, Governor Ronald Reagan of California 28,151, 2.77% and Senator Charles M. Percy of Illinois 15,152
or 1.49% of the votes cast.

Breakthrough For The Slums
Over the past year, Maryland has produced a mediocre crop of
political leaders - - Governor Agnew,County Executive Dale Anderson, gubernatorial aspirant George Mahoney (now running for a
Senate seat), et al. However, despite our scepticism last fall, Baltimore's freshman mayor, Thomas D'Alesandro, is proving to be one
of the few promising personalities in Maryland politics.
We are particularly impressed with Mayor D'Alesandro's recent
proposals for alleviating the crisis of the Inner City. This past week,
D'Alesandro presented a plan to recruit black residents of the city to
buy and reopen Inner City businesses which white merchants are unloading largely due to the unfortunate destruction of the riots. Furthermore, D'Alesandro wants to offer crash-training programs to
potential black storeowners in order to prepare them for operating
these businesses.
The importance of such a program cannot be overemphasized and
the mayor deserves praise for the insight he has shown.The Moynihan
studies of New York have shown the importance of developing entrepeneurial classes among depressed minority groups. The abilities
of immigrant groups such as the Jews, Italians or Irish to develop,
such a class proved to be keys to upward social mobility. America's
Negro population, with their unique historical development due, of
course, mainly to their past enslavement, have never been able to
emulate this formation of an entrepeneurial class. Hopefully,
Mayor D'Alesandro's program will be a beginning to correct this
situation and to provide the Inner City Negro with some of the
means for self-help.
This plan is only indicative of the overall progressive attitude
which the Mayor has displayed. Belatedly,we would like to commend
him for refusing to be caught in the post-riot onrush of backlash, a la
Agnew. Perhaps, the Mayor may turn out to be one factor which
will allow a "cool" summer to prevail in Baltimore.

The Siege At Homewood
When a situation involving the projected use of a measure such as
chemical Mace arises, any discussion of the issue is endangered by
emotionalism. A case in point was the biological warfare dispute
which occurred last year. There is also the danger of trying to create
a great debate over an issue which is relatively insignificant when
compared to the crises in our society today.
In this vein, we only wish to raise a few questions for future discussion concerning the University's prospective purchase of Mace.
Basically, we wonder why the Plant Manager's office feels that
the purchase of Mace is necessary. Incidents involving small groups
of offenders were cited as justification. Yet, how effective or necessary is Mace for the control of random incidents provoked by scattered, disorganized groups? We can see no justification for the contention that Hopkins will be menaced by crowds such as those which
amassed at Columbia or those which occur in riot situations - - and
it is in these cases where the use of Mace, if justified at all, is most
effective.
There is also a question which has ramifications for future discussions. Should the plant manager's office have the authority to initiate
such measures without a general consultation of affected segments
of the University? It seems to us that the decision would have remained completely in Wesley Taylor's hands if some student and
faculty members had not found out about his plans and protested.
Finally, we are worried about the planned distribution of Mace to
the elderly men who comprise the staffs of night watchmen and
campus police. Trained police and riot control forces have shown
past indiscriminate use of these weapons. Who will vouch for the
capabilities of Hopkins security force whose job is largely to ticket
errant cars? Mace, carelessly used at close range as would be the case
judging from the incidents cited at Hopkins involving small groups,
has caused both temporary and permanent damage. If the Hopkins
security people are as potentially outnumbered and threatened as it
is claimed, the caliber of the men who comprise it should be exhaustively assessed before they are armed with guns, much less Mace.
These are questions which must be asked and with the upcoming
meetings of the Academic Council and Committee of Student Affairs,
we hope that they will be fully explored.

course, mainly to their past enslavement, have never been able to
emulate this formation of an entrepeneurial class. Hopefully,
Mayor D'Alesandro's program will be a beginning to correct this
situation and to provide the Inner City Negro with some of the
means for self-help.
This plan is only indicative of the overall progressive attitude
which the Mayor has displayed. Belatedly,we would like to commend
him for refusing to be caught in the post-riot onrush of backlash, a la
Agnew. Perhaps, the Mayor may turn out to be one factor which
will allow a "cool" summer to prevail in Baltimore.

The Siege At Homewood
When a situation involving the projected use of a measure such as
chemical Mace arises, any discussion of the issue is endangered by
emotionalism. A case in point was the biological warfare dispute
which occurred last year. There is also the danger of trying to create
a great debate over an issue which is relatively insignificant when
compared to the crises in our society today.
In this vein, we only wish to raise a few questions for future discussion concerning the University's prospective purchase of Mace.
Basically, we wonder why the Plant Manager's office feels that
the purchase of Mace is necessary. Incidents involving small groups
of offenders were cited as justification. Yet, how effective or necessary is Mace for the control of random incidents provoked by scattered, disorganized groups? We can see no justification for the contention that Hopkins will be menaced by crowds such as those which
amassed at Columbia or those which occur in riot situations - - and
it is in these cases where the use of Mace, if justified at all, is most
effective.
There is also a question which has ramifications for future discussions. Should the plant manager's office have the authority to initiate
such measures without a general consultation of affected segments
of the University? It seems to us that the decision would have remained completely in Wesley Taylor's hands if some student and
faculty members had not found out about his plans and protested.
Finally, we are worried about the planned distribution of Mace to
the elderly men who comprise the staffs of night watchmen and
campus police. Trained police and riot control forces have shown
past indiscriminate use of these weapons. Who will vouch for the
capabilities of Hopkins security force whose job is largely to ticket
errant cars? Mace, carelessly used at close range as would be the case
judging from the incidents cited at Hopkins involving small groups,
has caused both temporary and permanent damage. If the Hopkins
security people are as potentially outnumbered and threatened as it
is claimed, the caliber of the men who comprise it should be exhaustively assessed before they are armed with guns, much less Mace.
These are questions which must be asked and with the upcoming
meetings of the Academic Council and Committee of Student Affairs,
we hope that they will be fully explored.
